intro: Dryadella vasquezii, commonly known as the Vasquez's dryad, is a rare flowering plant native to the arid regions of central Mexico. It belongs to the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its striking, tubular flowers that range in color from violet to deep purple. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and thrives in full sun, showcasing a compact, shrub-like form. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in a fine, white pubescence, adding to its unique appearance. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, it is considered endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
